citation.article-title: Mycobacterium palustre sp. nov., a potentially pathogenic, slowly growing mycobacterium isolated from clinical and veterinary specimens and from Finnish stream waters
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium palustre sp. nov.
Mycobacterium palustre (pa'lus.tre. L. adj. palustre living in swamps, referring to the isolation of most members of this novel species from peatland run-off water)
Cells are acid- and alcohol-fast bacilli.
Visible growth from a dilute inoculum requires 2-3 weeks.
Mature colony size is reached in 4 weeks at 36 °C.
Growth occurs at temperatures between 30 and 42 °C, 36 °C being regarded as the optimum temperature.
Growth at 45 °C is detected from a heavy inoculum on Middlebrook agar after 5-6 weeks.
Colonies on egg-based media and Middlebrook agar are smooth, scotochromogenic at 36 °C and photochromogenic or scotochromogenic at 42 °C.
The species yields positive results in urease, pyrazinamidase, acid phosphatase and Tween 80 hydrolysis tests and variable results in nitrate reduction and alkaline phosphatase tests.
Test results are negative for semi-quantitative catalase (45 mm foam), α-galactosidase and β-galactosidase.

In GLC analyses, M. palustre is characterized by the presence of notable amounts of 2-Me-20:0, 24:0 and 26:0 in addition to minor amounts of 2-Me-10:0, 2-Me-19:0, 2,9-diMe-20:0, 14-phe-14:0 and 2-Me-16-phe-16:0.
Phylogenetic analysis, based on 16S rDNA sequences, places M. palustre among the slowly growing mycobacteria, being most closely related to M. kubicae.
The type strain is strain E846T (=ATCC BAA-377T=DSM 44572T), isolated from water from a stream in Finland.
A veterinary isolate (strain 629) has also been deposited in the DSMZ, as DSM 44571.
